fields.description:
Currently, the App migration platform was release in an alpha stage. The alpha platform is a set of stable APIs provided to Marketplace partners so they can implement their migration path for CCMA and JCMA. Release posts:
 * [https://community.developer.atlassian.com/t/build-your-server-data-center-to-cloud-migration-path-with-the-app-migration-platform/40804]
 * [https://community.developer.atlassian.com/t/build-your-server-data-center-to-cloud-migration-path-with-the-app-migration-platform-continued/41204]
 * [https://community.developer.atlassian.com/t/build-your-server-data-center-to-cloud-migration-path-with-the-app-migration-platform-final-steps-release/41391]

While Marketplace partners use these APIs, the App migration platform team is working on finishing it by addressing its production readiness.

*{color:#ff0000}The current alpha platform has a security issue that makes it not suitable for production migrations involving real customer data.{color}*
fields.summary: App Migration Platform production readiness

fields.description:
Better Document that Jira Projects in the Trash will export to a Server XML backup properly, but attachments will be missing. Alternatively, export attachments for projects in the trash to avoid confusion.
h3. Steps to Replicate

1) Create a test project
 2) Add some attachments 
 3) Delete the project so that it goes to the trash
 4) Create a Server Backup, including attachments

The backup will include all the metadata for the deleted project, but the attachments will not be included in the backup. This will result in the project being imported into Server, without attachments, causing confusion.
fields.summary: Better Document that Jira Projects in the Trash will export to XML properly, but attachments will be missing

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
* In Jira Cloud, the project key must contain only alphanumeric characters and any symbols is not supported.
* In Jira Server, admins can modify the project key pattern and allow the project key to contains special characters.
** [Changing the project key format|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/changing-the-project-key-format-938847081.html]

The unsupported project key is causing issues on different features on both Jira and Confluence, such as:
* [MIG\-119: Attachments Upload Doesn't Work When The Project Key Contains Underscore Value|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/MIG-119]
* [JRACLOUD\-71232: Jira doesn't convert special character in the project's name to URLs|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-71232]
* [CONFCLOUD\-68055: Hyperlinks inside /jira macro not rendering correctly in the new editor|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-68055]

h3. Steps to Reproduce
#  On Jira Server, update the configuration to allow 'underscore' value as the project key pattern as per [Changing the project key format|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/changing-the-project-key-format-938847081.html]
{code}[A-Z][A-Z_0-9]+{code} # Create a project with special character on project key, eg: U_SCORE
# Take a backup of the Jira Server and import into Cloud

h3. Expected Results
Jira Cloud should prompt a warning to saying the backup contains unsupported project key and reject the import.

h3. Actual Results
No warning/error, the import was done successfully.

h3. Workaround
Update the project key to a name without an underscore
fields.summary: Jira Site Import allows the import of unsupported Project Key

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

At the moment JCMA only supports filter shares of the following types:
{code}
global
loggedin
project
group
project_unknown
{code}

While JIRA can have filter share types of:
{code}
user
global
loggedin
project
group
project-unknown
user-unknown
group-unknown
{code}

h3. Suggested Solution

Enhance JCMA so it can import the rest of the filter share types.
fields.summary: Support further filter share types

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

As per issue summary the back button for Trello importer does not work.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Attempt to import a Trello board to JIRA.
# On the page where you can specify user emails for the Trello users, the back button in question can be seen at the bottom of the page.

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Expected Results

The back button should bring you back to the previous page.

h3. Actual Results

Back button doesn't work.

h3. Workaround

No workaround as of now.
fields.summary: The Trello importer back button does not work

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

While the export to CSV file function adjusts the date times automatically depending on the user time zone which is ok, the Import CSV function does not care about the personal settings making the exported dates and imported dates might no match for different times zones.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Set your time zone to GMT-8 and export one the issue to CSV
 # Set your time zone to GMT-5 and export the same issue to CSV
 # Both dates are 3 hours adjusted. Which is ok
 # Import the CSV file GMT-8  with Jira Settings on GMT-8 results ok
 # Import the CSV file GMT-5 with Jira Settings on GMT-8, it is not adjusted. 

h3. Expected Results

The time should be atomically adjusted during the import function. 
h3. Actual Results

The original time and imported time are out of phase.
h3. Workaround

Adjust the times 3 hours manually.
fields.summary: The date fields imported via CSV are out of phase

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Using the UI, you can add an issue only to one sprint at the time: an active sprint or a future sprint.

Using the CSV importer under the External System Import feature, Jira allows issues to be added to an active sprint and a future sprint at the same time, causing several side effects in the reports and boards

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Jira classic project
# Add issues to the project
# Create 2 sprints in this project
# Add some issues to one of the sprints and start it
# Export the issues of this project to a CSV file
# Edit the CSV file including one more "Sprint" column and add a reference to the future sprint in the issues added to the started sprint. Save the file
# Import the CSV file
# Verify the issues

h3. Expected Results

The import CSV fails and an error message says that the file isn't valid

h3. Actual Results

The import succeed and the issues are added to both sprints


h3. Workaround

Edit the "Sprint" field of the affected issues via UI, adding them only to the active sprint
fields.summary: The CSV file importer allows users to add issues to an active and a future sprint at the same time

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When importing CSV files, it's possible to set the "Create date" value of the issues. You can set a date and time in the future and the CSV file accepts it, showing in the UI the create date in the future. You can have the create date set to a date after the last update date value

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Create a project and add issues to it
# Export the issues to a CSV file
# Edit the CSV file, setting the "Created" value to a date and time in the future
# Import the CSV file into Jira, mapping the field to make it update the issues, instead of creating new ones (mapping the "Issue Key" and "Issue Id" values)
# Look at the Created date of the issues

h3. Expected Results

The CSV import feature compares the current date and the date in the field  informs that the "Created" date is an invalid date

h3. Actual Results

The CSV file imports the issues and set the created date of the issue to the future date set in the CSV file.

h3. Workaround

Export the affected issues into a CSV file, set the "Created" date to a previous time and then import the file with the fixed dates
fields.summary: The CSV file import accept issues' create dates in the future
External system import fails to import attachments via JSON if there are keys "name" with the same value

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When a custom field has a context that is not set to global, meaning that it only appears in certain issue types, this custom field will not appear in the Map fields (3rd step) in the CSV import.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Have a custom field context applied to only a few issue types
 # Perform a CSV import in *External System Import*
 # The field will not appear on the map fields (3rd step) of the import

h3. Expected Results
* The field should appears in the drop-down list

h3. Actual Results
* The field doesn't appear.


h3. Workaround
* Edit the field context and make it applicable for all issue types.
fields.summary: Custom field without Global issue types context will not appear in the map list when importing CSV file

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

You can control the max file size for JSON imports by modifying the *Attachments* settings, as shown below in the file picker section:
 !Screen Shot 2020-08-24 at 09.59.52.png|thumbnail! 

Currently, even though the JSON file's size is under the acceptable size as it was configured, Jira won't proceed with the upload, showing an error message if the file is bigger than around 7.8 MB:
 !error.png|thumbnail! 

*"Cannot attach file <file_name.json>: You do not have permission to attach a file to the issue."*

h3. Steps to Reproduce

* Set the maximum attachment size to more than 10MB;
* Create a JSON file with size at 8MB or more (as long as it is smaller than what you have set as the maximum size);
* Try importing the file via the JSON external system import (https://YOUR_SITE.atlassian.net/secure/admin/JsonSetupPage!default.jspa?externalSystem=com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jim-plugin%3AjsonImporter)

h3. Expected Results

Jira will upload the file if it is smaller than the max size that was configured in the *Attachments* section.

h3. Actual Results

Jira fails to upload the file, presenting an error message.

h3. Workaround

Reduce the size of the file to 7.6MB or lower.
fields.summary: Import fails if JSON file is bigger than around 7.8 MB

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The Epic status field is a locked field, and it is used to control whether an Epic has been completed or not.

When an Epic is completed, it is removed from the Epic panel in the backlog of a board.

Currently, it is possible to create additional values in that field via CSV.

There are some problems that come with that:
* When you mark an Epic as Done in the Epic panel, it will set the most recent value that was added to the field instead of *Done*;
** You can bulk update the Epic status of Epic(s), but that may be misleading for users as they will set the Epics to *Done*, but the Epic will remain in the Epic panel since now the Epics will be considered as done only when they have the new value set;
** Users will not be able to remove those values from the field because it is locked.


h3. Steps to Reproduce

* Prepare a CSV file containing information from an existing Epic: Key, Summary, and Epic status. Leave the Summary column empty:
 !Screen Shot 2019-11-07 at 12.34.54.png|thumbnail! 
* Import that file via the *External System Import* section;
* You can perform an advanced search, and see the Epic status value in that Epic;
* Mark an Epic as Done in the Epic panel of a board, and check that the value set is the new one that was created;
* If you bulk update the Epic status of Epics to Done, they will remain in the Epic panel.

h3. Expected Results

There should not be an option to map the *Epic status* field during the CSV import.

h3. Actual Results

You can import values into the *Epic status* field.

h3. Workaround

If you run into a problem with new values in the Epic status field, contact the support.
fields.summary: It is possible to create options in the Epic status field via CSV import

h3. Environment

Jira Cloud
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a CSV file with some issues. Make sure to set at least one column issue type with the value *Story* ( [^CSV example.csv] );
 # Create an Agility project;
 # Jira home -> *Settings* -> *System* -> *External System Import* -> *CSV*;
 # Perform the import.

h3. Expected Results

Jira should not treat the Story issue type as it was not in a global scope.
h3. Actual Results

It looks like the Stories are treated as in a project scope and the import process will fail.
h3. Workaround

Changing the issue type of the affected issues in the CSV (e.g. from Story to Task), will make it possible to perform the import.

h3. Update

This is affecting JSON files as well.
fields.summary: Import via CSV will fail if there are issues with the Story issue type and there is an Agility project created in the instance

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Importing issues from Trello throws a 500 error in new sites. The issue hasn't been observed in older sites. It could be replicated in at least 2 sites created in December.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a new site or use a site created in December 2019.
 # Navigate to External System Import -> Trello  ->  Setup  ->   Next

h3. Expected Results
Should land in a page that asks to *Allow* or *Deny* access to Trello.

h3. Actual Results

A 500 Internal Server Error as below is thrown
 !Screenshot 2020-01-01 at 7.42.20 PM.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround

 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Trello Import to Jira throws 500 error

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When performing CSV attachment import with incorrect credentials, Jira shows that the import is successful (even the attachment actually failed to be retrieved from the source instance)
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Prepare CSV file and put the wrong email address. For an example, "*something@test.com*" is the correct one, but in this case, we can put "*something@tes.com*" (remove"t")
 # In this example, there is already existing ticket (ABC-123) and I import the attachment from Cloud instance A to Cloud instance B.
 ** The issue happen even if there is no existing ticket created yet.
 ** Make sure the user have Jira admin permission in both instances.
 # Perform CSV import
 ** Sample CSV file:
{noformat}
Summary, issue type, attachment, issuekey
Testing, Story, 20/May/20 10:00 AM;admin;<file name and type>;https://<prefix_email%40domain>:<token>@<URL>.atlassian.net/secure/attachment/<pid>/<filename>,ABC-123
{noformat}

h3. Expected Results

Jira shows the error for the incorrect credentials and attachment should not get imported.
h3. Actual Results

Jira continues with the import without showing any error. Also, the attachment is still added but in HTML type (not the real attachment since the authentication failed); making users to believe the import is successful but, actually it failed.
{noformat}
HTML document, ASCII text, with very long lines, with no line 
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Check both email and token and make sure they are the correct ones.
fields.summary: CSV attachment import failed silently using incorrect credential

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When using the non-admin CSV import tool, the "Validate" feature is giving a false error when validating a CSV with Parent/Sub-task. Clicking on "Begin Import" with the same CSV and configuration will import the issues successfully with no errors.
h3. Environment
 * Atlassian Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Go to the non-admin CSV importer by going to the Issue Navigator, and clicking on the "..." on the top right -> Import issues from CSV
 # Use this file [^Test-Link.csv] which contains this:
{code:java}
Summary, Issue Type, Issue ID, Parent ID
First Issue, Task, 1,
Second Issue, Sub-Task, , 1
{code}

 # Select any project, leave the other settings as default.
 # Map the CSV fields accordingly. (Summary:Summary, Issue Type:Issue Type, Parent ID:Parent Id, Issue ID:Issue Id)
 # On the page with the "Begin Import" and "Validate" buttons, click on "Validate".

h3. Expected Results

The Validation should pass through successfully without any errors.
h3. Actual Results

The validation returns this error:
{code:java}
The validation process has found 1 error/s
- Fatal error during import: Parent Issue cannot be null
{code}
h3. Notes
 * Although the Validation returns an error, the import will be successful if the user clicks on the "Begin Import" button.
 * Even when using the example CSV file for Sub-tasks provided in [the documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/importing-data-from-csv-776636762.html], the same error is returned when validating.

Here are the Validation logs:

2018-01-05 13:09:12,238 ERROR - Fatal error during import: Parent Issue cannot be null {code}
Here are the logs when the file is actually imported (without making any changes):
{code:java}
2018-01-05 10:03:22,732 INFO - Importer started!
2018-01-05 10:03:22,740 INFO - Engine is running in Import mode
2018-01-05 10:03:22,951 INFO - All issues will be imported to project: Monopoly (MON)

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Backup restore fails if Service Desk customers are using subdomain email. For example, you can add a Jira Service Desk customer using an email like "firstnamelastname@something.domain.com", but if you create a backup file and try to restore it, the restore fails

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Jira site including Jira Service Desk and Jira Software or Jira Core
# Create a Jira Service Desk project and add a customer using an email using a subdomain like *firstnamelastname@something.domain.com*
# Create other projects and add issues to them
# Generate a backup file via *Jira settings > System > Backup manager*
# Create another site and restore the backup created above via **Jira settings > System > Restore system*

h3. Expected Results

The backup data is restored, as the JSD project accepted the user's creation with the email "firstnamelastname@something.domain.com"

h3. Actual Results

The backup restore fails with the message:

{quote}
An error occurred during the import process.

Import again with a different file or get in touch with our support team. Include the steps you followed, along with any unique characteristics of your Jira setup.

* Cannot start import - someone's email is not valid: firstnamelastname@something.domain.com
{quote}

h3. Workaround

As it's not possible to edit the email address of a Jira Service Desk customer, you need to

* Remove the user or
* Adjust the XML of the backup file and adjust the email to something like "firstnamelastname@domain.com"
fields.summary: Backup restore fails if Service Desk customers are using subdomain email

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Using the CSV import, it's not possible to import the *Account* Custom Field provided by Tempo. The importer cannot match the value in the CSV with the existing 'Account' field value.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an Account in Tempo -> Accounts and assign to a project
# Create a CSV file with an 'Account' column with the same value as the Account Name that you've previously created
# Try to import the CSV file mapping the Account column with the Account field in Jira

h3. Expected Results
The Import will successfully create/update the issues with the 'Account' value defined in the CSV file.

h3. Actual Results
If the 'Account' field *is not* required in the Field Configuration, the issue will be properly created *without* the 'Account' value

If the 'Account' field *is* required in the Field Configuration, the import will fail with the following error:
{quote}
Issue can't be created due to the error/s [ Account is required. ]
{quote}

h3.Workaround
- If the field isn't required, remove the 'Account' column from the CSV file and add the value manually after the issues were created.

- Set the 'Account' field as optional in the Field Configuration
fields.summary: Unable to import CSV file with 'Account' custom field. The value isn't mapped.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

CSV imports to user picker fields favors portal customer accounts over Jira user accounts which means that if 1 email has both a Jira user account and a portal customer account, the import will automatically map to the portal customer account rather than the Jira user account.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Jira user account and portal customer account using the same email
# Perform a CSV import to a user picker field (eg: assignee) using the email as the value

h3. Expected Results

The expected outcome would be that the *Assignee* field would be updated and mapped to the Jira user linked to the email value in the CSV file.

h3. Actual Results

Instead, the portal customer is mapped to the *Assignee* field.

h3. Workaround

The workaround is to use the accountId in your CSV file for user mapping instead of the email address. Alternatively, you could also delete the portal customer account so that the Jira user is the only one that exists with the email.
fields.summary: CSV import to user picker fields favors portal customers

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-61755].
  {panel}

h3. Description
Customer have a CSV file and contains a description filed. The value of the description file is formatted to have line break between lines. When customer import the CSV file and tick the Map field value option, JIRA will remove the line break between lines and import. 

h3. Step to reproduce
# Create a CSV file and add a description column.
# Enter multiple sentence and line break between the sentence for description field
!image-2016-07-01-20-51-47-221.png|thumbnail! 
# Login to JIRA
# Go to External Import System
# Upload the CSV file
# Proceed to Map fields page
# Tick *Map field value* for description field and click next
!image-2016-07-01-20-51-09-513.png|thumbnail! 
# JIRA show the description value without any space between lines
!image-2016-07-01-20-50-47-426.png|thumbnail!
# Click Begin Import
# Check the imported issue and found out the line break between sentence is removed.
!image-2016-07-01-20-52-39-458.png|thumbnail! 
 

h3. Expected Result
JIRA should not remove the line breaks and space between paragraph and sentences when import.
!image-2016-07-01-20-53-00-490.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
Do not tick the *Map field value* option in Map value page
fields.summary: CSV import do not create line break for text field when user tick the Map field value option

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The importer fails when  trying to import against a custom field that has multiple issue type scope.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a custom field (ie. Custom Summary)
 # Add a context and restrict it to issue type Bugs
 # Add a second context and restrict it to issue type Task
 # Import a new *Story* issue via JSON and populate the Custom Summary field.

 !Config.png|thumbnail! 


h3. Expected Results

The JSON importer should be able to handle the data or error out gracefully specifying which custom field cannot be handled. 

ie. Error : Custom Summary is currently not available for issue Type Story.

h3. Actual Results

The importer fails with a vague error and there is no indication which custom field was causing the error 

 !error import.png|thumbnail! 

{code}
ERROR - Unexpected failure occurred. Importer will stop immediately. Data may be in an unstable state: expected one element but was: 
<com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.config.FieldConfigSchemeImpl@c048c6ab, com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.config.FieldConfigSchemeImpl@60a994b5>
{code}

This gets problematic when there is a huge number of custom fields being imported. 

h3. Workaround

Check the custom fields configurations one by one to see which one could be causing the failure.
fields.summary: JSON importer unable to handle a custom field with multiple issue type scopes

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

CSV import fails if status ID conflicts with status name

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new status in Jira with the name: 3
# Import the attached CSV file using external import tool:  [^test.csv] 
# Make sure to map 'In Progress' status. If the project you're importing in to does not have the status in the workflow you'll need to add it.

h3. Expected Results

Issue is imported successfully with status set to 'In Progress'

h3. Actual Results

Issue is not imported and following error is seen:

{noformat}
Error importing issue [externalId='autoid-8809367067477563620', summary='CSV Import Test']: Status [ 3 ] does not have a linked step in the [ Software Simplified Workflow for Project ] workflow. Please map to a different status.

fields.description:
*Steps to Reproduce*:
 # Delete the Developers Role from JIRA.
 # Confirm to delete the role when being reminded.
 # The permission scheme will remove Developers role from the permissions.
 # Create a Test Project.
 # Navigate to _JIRA Administration > System > External System Import_ and choose CSV Import.
 # Import the [^AtlassianTestCSV (1).csv] and choose the previous Test project as the target project.
 # Finish the Import.

*Expected Result*:
The issue is imported without any problem and the assignee field will used what have been specified in the CSV file.

*Actual Result*:
Same as the expected result above, but will be creating the Developers Role in the process and included those users inside.

*Notes*:
While the user who are assigned to those issue will stays even without having _"Assignable User"_ permission, the user would be included in the Developers Role which also does not have the permission.

This should not be a problem if there is only several user on the CSV file, but if importing hundred of issues with unique users could lead to a problem where it would not possible to access Project People/Roles due to amount of users in that role.

*Workaround* 

The issue only replicates on CSV importer via the External System Import. Use the [non-admin CSV importer|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiracorecloud/creating-issues-using-the-csv-importer-765593817.html] in the Jira search page.

 !import.png|thumbnail!

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Trello Importer is using username to map the users in Jira instead of email address.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Login into your Trello site
 # Navigate to Profile and Visibility and change your username to someone who does not exist in Jira site anymore.
# Now, create few cards in Trello .
# Go to Jira site, Use the Trello import from “External system import” to import the cards into Jira.
# When the option to provide email address is shown. Provide your email address which is active in Jira site.
# Complete the import.

h3. Expected Results
Import should map the issues based on email address provided during the import.

h3. Actual Results
No matter what email we provide , Trello import is taking the username of the importer . In this case issues are mapped to user who is no longer present in Jira.



h3. Workaround
# Export any issue in Jira where you are the Reporter or Assignee . Make sure to export the columns Reporter/Assignee
# Note down the username in the .csv file
# Now set this username is Trello.
fields.summary: Importing issues in Jira via Trello importer is not considering email address provided , it's taking usernames instead.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

You can control the max file size for CSV imports by modifying the *Attachments* settings, as shown below in the file picker section:
  !Screen Shot 2020-10-13 at 16.41.56.png|thumbnail! 

Currently, even though the CSV file's size is under the acceptable size as it was configured, Jira won't proceed with the upload, showing an error message if the file is bigger than around 22 MB:
 !Screen Shot 2020-10-13 at 16.40.58.png|thumbnail! 

*"Cannot attach file <file_name.csv>: You do not have permission to attach a file to the issue."*

h3. Steps to Reproduce

* Se the maximum attachment size to more than 20MB;
* Create a CSV file with size at 22MB or more (as long as it is smaller than what you have set as the maximum size);
* Try importing the file via the CSV external system import (https://YOUR_SITE.atlassian.net/secure/admin/CsvSetupPage!default.jspa?externalSystem=com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jim-plugin%3AcsvImporter)

h3. Expected Results

Jira will upload the file if it is smaller than the max size that was configured in the *Attachments* section.

h3. Actual Results

Jira fails to upload the file, presenting an error message.

h3. Workaround

Reduce the size of the file to 22MB or lower.
fields.summary: Import fails if CSV file is bigger than around 22 MB

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-64599].
{panel}
h3. Summary

The issue Created Event is not triggered when issue are created from CSV using External System Import (documentation: [importing data from csv|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/importing-data-from-csv-776636762.html]). The issue updated event is fired instead.

This makes it impossible to trigger automation rules, notifications or webhooks for issues created this way.

When bulk creating issues from CSV  (documentation: [create issues using the csv importer|https://support.atlassian.com/jira-core-cloud/docs/create-issues-using-the-csv-importer/]) the issue created event is correctly fired.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a Webhook that fires on issue_created and issue_updated events and send the data to [beeceptor|https://beeceptor.com/], [webhooks.site|https://webhook.site/], [postbin|https://postb.in/], or other similar tools
 # Bulk create some issues from CSV ([create issues using the csv importer|https://support.atlassian.com/jira-core-cloud/docs/create-issues-using-the-csv-importer/])
 # See that you have correctly received the issue_created Webhook
 # Now repeat the test using External System Import instead ([importing data from csv|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/importing-data-from-csv-776636762.html])

h3. Expected Results

The issue_created webhook is received
h3. Actual Results

The issue_updated webhook is received instead.
h3. Notes

This happens because the CSV External System Import is firing the issue updated event instead of the issue created event. The issue can also be reproduced using notifications or automation rules configured to be triggered on issue_updated event.

From original description:
{quote}I am creating an plugins which send and notification to our tool whenever an Issue is created. We are unable to trapped the Issue Created Event at the time of CSV import.

Even We are unable to distinct the issue which are created using CSV import.
{quote}
h3. Workaround

For Issue Created event, use Bulk Create instead.

(!) Bulk Create has more limited features than CSV External System Import (!)
fields.summary: Issue Created Event is not fired when creating issues using CSV External System Import

fields.description:
h3.Summary

When importing boards over from Trello (external importer not CSV), created next-gen projects has open access by default. This allows other users to access the project which is very detrimental if said Trello board contains sensitive information.

h3.Steps to Reproduce

Try importing a JSON board over to JIRA. The board will be created as a new project with open access to all users.

h3. Expected Results

The project should be created with *private* access instead of open.

h3. Current Results

Newly project is created with open access which allows every user to look at it.

h3. Workaround

No workaround this for now besides changing the access immediately after the JSON board migration.
fields.summary: Trello import should allow user to specify next-gen project access
JSON importer does not accept accountIDs for history data

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When trying to permanently delete a project the deletion will fail without sharing in-depth details of the issue.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Move a project to JIRA's trash can.
 # Access the trash and try to permanently delete it.

{code:java}
We’re deleting your project
It may take a while to delete the project. {code}
h3. Expected Results

After some time the project should vanish from the trash can, meaning it was completely deleted.
h3. Actual Results

The user that triggered the deletion should receive an email with the below message:
 !image.png|thumbnail!
{code:java}
We couldn't delete this project.
It's probably a temporary problem. Go to trash and try again. {code}
h3. Workaround

No workaround for the issue at the moment.
 Please engage Atlassian Support.
fields.summary: Permanently deleting project fails

fields.description:
h3. Summary
* CSV External system import in spanish is not working if uploaded file contains non-ASCII characters.
* The "Next" button is grayed. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to Personal settings > change language to Spanish
# Save changes
# Go to "Importar sistema externo" (External System Import) 
# Click on "Importación a partir de Archivo CSV" 
# If the uploaded file contains non-ASCII characters the button "Next" is grayed
# Warning that shows up: "El archivo CSV que ha proporcionado contiene caracteres fuera del conjunto ASCII. Asegúrese de fijar la codificación correctamente."
#*  !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

Note: This does not happen for English version: 
* Warning that shows up: "The CSV file you uploaded contains non-ASCII characters. Make sure to set the right encoding."
*  !screenshot-2.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Expected Results
* The button "Next" shows up
* The import succeeds if the correct file encoding is chosen. 
* The import succeeds if the wrong file encoding is chosen but warnings will show up in the logs.  

h3. Actual Results
* For spanish language: 
** A warning is thrown: "El archivo CSV que ha proporcionado contiene caracteres fuera del conjunto ASCII. Asegúrese de fijar la codificación correctamente."
** The "Next" button is grayed.
** It remains grayed also if changing the "File encoding" value. 

* For English version: 
** A warning is thrown: "The CSV file you uploaded contains non-ASCII characters. Make sure to set the right encoding."
** The "Next" button is not grayed. 


h3.Workaround
* Changing the language settings of the profile to "English" fixes the issue

h3. Notes
* Please check First internal comment for extra details.
fields.summary: CSV External system import is not working if uploaded file contains non-ASCII characters and default language is not English

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The 'Stop Import' function in External System Importer doesn't stop the import process
h3. Environment
 * Jira 4f218d83

h3. Steps to Reproduce

 # Click on 'Stop Import'

h3. Expected Results

Import process is stopped
h3. Actual Results

{noformat}
h3. Workaround

 

None

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-41199].
{panel}
h3. Symptoms

After a migration, a full JIRA export is imported into a new instance, which means Confluence must be imported space by space.

Any existing links on JIRA tickets to Confluence pages (_Mentioned In_ links) are still to the old page ID so will not load.
h3. Testing

*First Approach*

I imported customer JIRA and Connie data and my dev instance ([https://adiallo.jira-dev.com|https://adiallo.jira-dev.com/]) and was able to reproduce the issue. In the JIRA issue, I was seeing the *Page Failed to load* under the *Issue Links* opposite the *mentioned in* option. That's the same way the customer is seeing it.

*Second Approach*
 # I created a JIRA issue in another dev instance ([https://stan.jira-dev.com/browse/BUR-5]) and mentioned in and Confluence page ([https://stan.jira-dev.com/wiki/display/ds/M%2Cz%3E%2Cxz%3Exz]) and the display was fine from both side.
 # I exported JIRA and Confluence from [https://stan.jira-dev.com|https://stan.jira-dev.com/] and imported it into: [https://adiallo.jira-dev.com|https://adiallo.jira-dev.com/].
 # After a successful import and reindex, the same error appear in the JIRA Issue ([https://adiallo.jira-dev.com/browse/BUR-5):] *Page Failed to load* and from Confluence side it throws: *JIRA Issues Macro: Unable to locate JIRA server for this macro. It may be due to Application Link configuration*.
fields.summary: JIRA keeps dead links to Confluence pages after migration and space import

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Cascading custom field value ( Parent Value -> Child Value) is not imported correctly when using CSV import from ( Issues and filters > Three dots button > Imports Issues from CSV).

h3. Environment
Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a multiple cascading custom field which have Parent Value and Child Value
# Then, create CSV file to import the issue. For example :-
 [^new_test.csv] 
# Then, import it from :-
## Go to Issue and Filters page
## Then , click the three dots button on the top right
## Then, choose *Imports Issues from CSV*
## Then, import the CSV file with mapped fields.

h3. Expected Results
The custom field update correctly with parent value and child value.

h3. Actual Results
Child value is not imported

h3.Workaround
Import the issue from *Systems > External System Import > CSV*
fields.summary: Cascading Custom Field not imported correctly from CSV import
Not possible to import JSON file to existing project

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

As per summary, the 'Being Import' button is grayed out if there are 2 users with similar names on the page.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Ensure that you have 2 users with the same name (but different email) over at your Trello board.
 # Attempt to import said board to JIRA.

h3. Expected Results

The 'Begin import' button should not be grayed out.

h3. Actual Results

The 'Begin import' button is grayed out despite different emails are assigned to the users with similar names.

 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround

Change the username over at Trello so that it does not share the same username. This has to be done from https://id.atlassian.com .

 !image-2020-07-30-19-47-42-343.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Trello import 'Begin Import' grays out if you have 2 users with similar username

fields.description:
Summary

CSV Reports containing the field 'Date of first response' does not obey to the selected timezone as other fields do (like created, updated). This can cause inconsistencies like reports having 'Date of first response' field being lower than the creation date.
h3. Environment

Tested within cloud environemnt
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an issue.
 # Comment on it.
 # Download a first csv report.
 # Go to user profile settings and change your timezone setting.
 # Take another report with the same issues.
 # Compare Date of first response with other date fields on both reports.

h3. Expected Results

The 'date of first response' field should obey to the same rules as other date fields like 'created' (get converted to the selected timezone)
h3. Actual Results

Date of first response is not converted to the timezone settings (remains unchanged)

h3. Workaround

Select Export HTML reports instead of CSV. For HTML reports the timezone works as expected.
fields.summary: Date of first response field does not obey to timezone settings as other fields

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When doing a CSV import (both via external system import, and bulk create issues option), the validation is successful if there is a validator in the *Create* transition, but the actual import is failing with no clear message.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Add a "Field Required Validator" to the "Create" transition in a workflow;
# Import from CSV with the required field(s) not present;
# Run the import.

h3. Expected Results

The import does not occur, but a message stating the reason would be displayed.

h3. Actual Results

Import fails without any clear error message:

Non-admin import:
{noformat}2019-08-26 08:36:06,087 INFO - Importer started!
2019-08-26 08:36:06,104 INFO - Engine is running in Import mode
2019-08-26 08:36:06,365 INFO - All issues will be imported to project: TEST (TEST)
2019-08-26 08:36:06,396 INFO - Creating issue: [externalId='autoid--4894869324873235288', summary='Test issue']
2019-08-26 08:36:06,413 INFO - Issue does not have issue type selected, the affected issues will be created with default issue type [Story]
2019-08-26 08:36:06,496 ERROR - Fatal error during import:{noformat}

External system import:
{noformat}
Error importing issue [externalId='autoid--7059959405534748340', summary='Test']: Unable to create issue: Test
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

Test out the create issue manually via the web interface. Populate the required fields (with asterisk) and leave the rest as blank. If the issue creation fails, check for any validator that needs to be handled in the CSV import.

Make sure that the validators in workflows in the project do not conflict with the test data. Disable the validators for the import if necessary, or add the required fields with values to your CSV file.
fields.summary: Import from CSV fails with no clear message if there are validators

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

As per bug ticket description. The 48 hours timer is inconsistently applied to backup generation. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Generate a JIRA Cloud backup *with* attachment.
 # Once backup from step 1 is generated, generate another backup again but this time *without* attachment. 
# There will be no 48 hours timer. 
# Clear the backup frequency restriction via database update (please refer to the private comments).
# Generate a backup *without* attachment.
# Once the backup is generated, generate a backup this time *with* attachment.
# JIRA Cloud complains about backup frequency.

h3. Expected Results

The 48 hours timer should be consistently applied.

h3. Actual Results

The 48 hours timer is not consistently applied.

h3. Workaround

No workaround as of now. If need the backup timer to be removed, please contact support.
fields.summary: Inconsistent backup timer behavior

fields.description:
h3. Expected Behavior
Issues will be imported based on the ID specified in CSV file, which will be discarded after the import process is complete. This scenario is suggested when importing issues and subtasks on [Importing data from CSV - Encapsulating JIRA data structure in your CSV file|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver071/importing-data-from-csv-802592885.html#ImportingdatafromCSV-EncapsulatingJIRAdatastructureinyourCSVfile]

h3. Actual Behavior
The values to the Issue ID field during a CSV import are saved to an "External Issue ID" field. When performing new imports, they will usually not work properly because it's rather difficult to find unique ID values. We should have two different options upon import: "Issue ID"  - a value that will only be used within that import process to link issues; and "External Issue ID" for when users want to map the ID that came from the source system.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Try to import a file containing the following data twice, mapping "id" to "Issue ID" and "parent id" to "Parent ID".
{code:none|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#6A8EB3|bgColor=#F8F8F8}
id,parent id,summary
1,,"Test"
,1,"Test sub-task"
{code}

The value set on "Issue ID" will be replicated to the "External Issue ID" value of the issue with summary "Test". Upon a new import, it will skip that issue and register the following on the import log:

{code:none|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#6A8EB3|bgColor=#F8F8F8}
External issue 1 already exists as PROJ-1, not importing.
{code}

h3. Notes

This may cause problems with sub-tasks links if you use the parent-id field as it will be mapped to the already existing external issue id and not the current CSV issue id.

h3. Workaround
fields.summary: Values mapped to "Issue ID" field upon import will be saved to "External Issue ID" custom field

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When importing issues from CSV, despite estimates being listed in seconds according to [Creating Issues using the CSV Importer|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRACLOUD/Creating+issues+using+the+CSV+importer] and [Importing Data from CSV|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRACLOUD/Importing+Data+from+CSV], if default unit for time tracking is set to *minutes*, it will be imported as minutes instead of hours.

h3. Environment
JIRA 6.5.*

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set Time Tracking default unit to Minutes (per [Configuring Time Tracking|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRACLOUD/Configuring+Time+Tracking#ConfiguringTimeTracking-ConfiguringTimeTrackingSettings])
# On a JIRA instance, *Issues > Import from CSV*
# Import the attached CSV
# Check the imported issues. Original Estimate will show 14m instead of 14h.

h3. Expected Results
Importer would convert the seconds to minutes and then hours/days if necessary.

h3. Actual Results
The minutes are converted to hours and then labeled as minutes. The default unit should only be used if not specified.
 
h3. Notes
For example, Original Estimate is listed in CSV as 50400 seconds > 840 minutes > 14 hours
Importer converts the 14 hours back to minutes, by default.
Importer should know that 50400 is listed as seconds.

h3.Solution / Workaround
# Change [Default Time Tracking|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRACLOUD/Configuring+Time+Tracking#ConfiguringTimeTracking-ConfiguringTimeTrackingSettings] unit to hours, and re-import the CSV issues.
# Confirm that Original Estimate shows correct time, and if desired, change the default time tracking back to minutes.
fields.summary: When importing issues from CSV, Original Estimate is imported as minutes instead of hours

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When importing CSV to JIRA with parents and sub-tasks, (at least) 3 problems may happen depending on how the parent/sub-tasks are set, all due to no validation in the CSV file:
# If we import a sub-task (using the 'sub-task' Issue Type') without a parent, a sub-task will be created without a parent. (Example [^problem1.csv]) - This problem was already reported as an old bug from 2015, initially reported to Server: [JRACLOUD-42405|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-42405]
# If we import 2 parents and set both of them as parents of a single sub-task, the sub-task will have 2 parents (Example  [^problem2.csv]) 
# If we import a sub-task having another sub-task as parent, it will have that sub-task as parent (Example [^problem3.csv]) 

h3. Identifying problems

We can check each problem and confirm them using the following queries:

h4. Problem 1: Sub-tasks without parents:
{code:sql}
select i.id as "child_id", ( p.pkey || '-' || i.issuenum ) as "child_key", it.pname as "child_type", it.pstyle as "child_type_style" from jiraissue i join project p on i.project = p.id join issuetype it on i.issuetype = it.id left join (select destination, source from issuelink where linktype in (select id from issuelinktype where linkname = 'jira_subtask_link') ) t on i.id = t.destination where it.pstyle = 'jira_subtask' and ( t.source not in (select id from jiraissue) or t.source is null) order by child_id desc;
{code}
|| child_id|| child_key|| child_type|| child_type_style|| 
| 10013| PCIT-12| Sub-task| jira_subtask| 

h4. Problem 2: Issue with duplicate parents
{code}
select i.id as "child_id", ( p.pkey || '-' || i.issuenum ) as "child_key", it.pname as "child_type", it.pstyle as "child_type_style", t.count as "number_of_parents", parent_i.id as "parent_id", ( parent_p.pkey || '-' || parent_i.issuenum ) as "parent_key", parent_it.pname as "parent_type", parent_it.pstyle as "parent_type_style" from jiraissue i join project p on i.project = p.id join issuetype it on i.issuetype = it.id join (select destination, count(*) from issuelink where linktype= (select id from issuelinktype where linkname = 'jira_subtask_link') group by destination having count(*) > 1) t on i.id = t.destination join issuelink parent_l on i.id = parent_l.destination join jiraissue parent_i on parent_l.source = parent_i.id join project parent_p on parent_p.id = parent_i.project join issuetype parent_it on parent_i.issuetype = parent_it.id where parent_l.linktype in (select id from issuelinktype where linkname = 'jira_subtask_link') order by child_id desc;
{code}
|| child_id|| child_key|| child_type|| child_type_style|| number_of_parents|| parent_id|| parent_key|| parent_type|| parent_type_style|| 
| 10012| PCIT-11| Sub-task| jira_subtask| 2| 10010| PCIT-9| Task| | 
| 10012| PCIT-11| Sub-task| jira_subtask| 2| 10011| PCIT-10| Task| | 

h4. Problem 3: Issues with sub-tasks as parents
{code:sql}
select i.id as "child_id", ( p.pkey || '-' || i.issuenum ) as "child_key", it.pname as "child_type", it.pstyle as "child_type_style", parent_i.id as "parent_id", ( parent_p.pkey || '-' || parent_i.issuenum ) as "parent_key", parent_it.pname as "parent_type", parent_it.pstyle as "parent_type_style" from jiraissue i join project p on i.project = p.id join issuetype it on i.issuetype = it.id join issuelink il on i.id = il.destination join jiraissue parent_i on il.source = parent_i.id join project parent_p on parent_p.id = parent_i.project join issuetype parent_it on parent_i.issuetype = parent_it.id where il.linktype in (select id from issuelinktype where linkname = 'jira_subtask_link') and it.pstyle = 'jira_subtask' and parent_it.pstyle = 'jira_subtask'
{code}
|| child_id|| child_key|| child_type|| child_type_style|| parent_id|| parent_key|| parent_type|| parent_type_style|| 
| 10015| PCIT-14| Sub-task| jira_subtask| 10014| PCIT-13| Sub-task| jira_subtask|


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Import [^problem1.csv] or [^problem2.csv] or [^problem3.csv]

h3. Expected Results
Issue are not created, because they would create an invalid state in JIRA.

h3. Actual Results
The issues are imported and invalid states mentioned above are created. Boards containing issues from problem 1 (and possible the others as well) break, generally showing a blank page.


h3.Workaround
If possible:
# Delete the broken issues
# Fix the CSV to have sub-tasks with only a single parent, no sub-tasks as parent
# Import it again

OR

# Move the child issue to the incorrect parent issue and move it back to the correct parent issue.

Or Contact [Atlassian Support|https://support.atlassian.com/contact/#/]
fields.summary: Lack of parent/sub-task validation in CSV import causes invalid state

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
CSV import (through issue navigator) fails to map the user for *User Picker* fields are set if using email address. The following error appears for validation:
 !User import.png|thumbnail! 

Even though the user is valid and email address is correct.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set a user picker field/column in CSV file with email address. For example
{noformat}
summary, description, owner, developer (custom field)
Test issue, testuser, testuser, <EMAILID>
{noformat}
# Assuming *developer* as the custom field for the user picker
# Perform CSV import through *Issue navigator* (search issue page) > *Import issues from CSV*

h3. Expected Results
Issue is created

h3. Actual Results
* Following error appears for validation:
 !User import.png|thumbnail! 


h3. Workaround
# Import through *Jira settings* > *System* > *External System Import* > *CSV Import*
# Or, Use AAID in the CSV file
fields.summary: CSV import fails to set user picker fields (e.g assignee, reporter, custom field)

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Importing issues via issue search > CSV import is adding the user who performed the import as a watcher of all imported issues.

The same does not apply to when we use the "External System Import" CSV import option, the user who performed the import is not added as a watcher of all imported issues.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a CSV file with an issue to import in Jira
 # Open the issue search and select the option to import issues via CSV.

h3. Expected Results

The issues are imported and the user who performed the CSV import will not be added as a watcher of any imported issue.
h3. Actual Results

The user who performed the import is being added as a watcher of all imported issues.
h3. Workaround

Use the "External System Import" CSV import option instead of the one available at the issue search page.
 # Choose !https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/files/945104532/953138831/1/1530296096612/cog.png|height=18! > *System*.
 # In the Import and Export section, click *External System Import* and then click *CSV*.
 # Choose your CSV source file.
fields.summary: Importing issues via issue search > CSV import is adding the user who performed the import as a watcher of all imported issues.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Importing History via JSON, it's not importing the first item defined in the JSON.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a JSON file that will create an issue with History
# Add only one History item, for example, a transition.

h3. Expected Results
It will be imported the item and transition the issue.

h3. Actual Results
It doesn't import the item.

h3. Workaround
Add another item equal to the original one.
fields.summary: Import Via JSON is not Importing the First Item from the History

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Generating Jira Server export and importing to Jira Cloud fails with the follow error:
{code:java}
Error importing data: com.google.gson.JsonSyntaxException: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Expected BEGIN_OBJECT but was STRING at line 1 column 2 path $]
{code}
 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 
# Create a backup in Jira Server 
# Import backup into Cloud 

h3. Expected Result
* Import is successful

h3. Actual Result

Import fails with the following error. 
{code:java}
Error importing data: com.google.gson.JsonSyntaxException: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Expected BEGIN_OBJECT but was STRING at line 1 column 2 path $]
{code}

Note: The error could be only seen from the logs
 
h3. More Information

* It potentially affects the instance easier if the backup file is taken from Jira Server that just recently import from Jira Cloud
* The issue occurs if there are local only dashboard items on the server instance. Such items do not have the <{{replace-gadget-spec-uri>}} element in their module descriptor.
fields.summary: Import Error caused by mismatch in json encoding

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

While restoring a Jira site backup, the following error is thrown

 
{code:java}
There was an error importing file xyz.zip: Validation failed. Following issues were reported:
Error importing data: java.lang.NullPointerException: userName{code}
 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Import a Server instance backup into Cloud through the Restore System menu

h3. Expected Results

Import completes successfully
h3. Actual Results

The above exception is thrown

 
h3. Workaround

This error may be thrown when users do not have a valid email address (name@domain.com). This can be addressed by finding and updating these user records in the xml file or on the Server instance before generating a new backup file.

These users might be missing an emailAddress entity in the xml altogether or have *an empty emailAddress* entity that looks like:
{code:java}
emailAddress=""
emailAddress=" "
email=""
email=" "{code}
*Note*: There should be a valid email. A NULL or spaces will not resolve this problem.
fields.summary: Site Import fails with Error: java.lang.NullPointerException: userName

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When importing a backup from a Jira Server application that has been recently entered/exited plugin safe mode, if the user tries to update apps, a message that "an error has occurred" will be displayed. If the user tries to import update it again, the process will eventually work.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # In a Jira Server instance, make sure to enter [plugin safe mode|https://confluence.atlassian.com/upm/disabling-and-enabling-apps-273875716.html#Disablingandenablingapps-Disablingorenablingallapps(usingSafeMode)]
 # Create a backup of the instance and import into a Jira Cloud one
 # Install an app and wait for it to have an update available
 # Try to tap the update button

h3. Expected Results

The app should be properly updated.
h3. Actual Results

The app does not get updated and displays a message that "an error has occurred". As some additional notes:
 * When installing apps, the same message might be triggered.
 * This is a similar behavior from this [recently closed bug in Jira Server|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-69188]
 * When accessing the *Audit logs* part of the *Manage Apps* menu, an error will be displayed (it can change to display different safe mode entries, like, "ENTER_SAFE_MODE":
Failed to parse AuditLogEntry from JSON string: 
{code}{"userKey":"nameoftheuser","date":currentdate,"i18nKey":"upm.auditLog.safeMode.exit.success","entryType":"EXIT_SAFE_MODE","params":[]}
{code}
A potential cause for this issue is that the backup includes entries that are only valid for the Jira Server edition (like safe mode). When a new entry is recorded to be updated to the Audit logs, the error is displayed because Jira is not able to add the entry, although the action to update/install the app works on the second try.

h3. Workaround

Tap the update button again to have the app updated. To have the issue fixed, contact support.
fields.summary: Unable to properly update apps after migrating from Jira Server

h3. Summary
When we perform a site restoration on Jira, it would wipe out all data, including the users
bq. Please note that this process will delete all existing Jira data in your site and replace it with data from the selected file.

However, we found the existing users are not deleted. Hence, it shows "UserAlreadyExists" when Jira tries to create the account for the same user who exists on both source and destination instance (especially the default add-on users).

h3. Environment
* Cloud -> Cloud restoration
* Server -> Cloud restoration

# Restore it on the same instance

h3. Expected Results

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-59868].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
During a JIRA import, if the export is from a JIRA that has a pending upgrade task in the database, this entry is migrated and causes the JIRA Upgrade task (after the import) to fail and permanently Lock JIRA.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Upgrade Tasks may appear as "Pending" in the *upgradehistory* db table if the DelayedUpgradeJobRunner introduced in JIRA 6.4 delayed the task.
# Export a JIRA that has a "Pending" task in the *upgradehistory* table.
# Import to latest JIRA

h3. Expected Results
JIRA imports and runs upgrade tasks

h3. Actual Results
*Update: 7/7/2016* - JIRA will allow the export, but will raise a validation error before beginning to import the backup file. This should allow the workaround to be applied directly and the import restarted.

Under the previous behaviour JIRA imports data but fails to run upgrade tasks with the following error in the logs:
{noformat}

{noformat}
JIRA is locked.

h3. Notes
On that particular case the following entry is found in the "entities.xml"
{noformat}

h3.Workaround
* Search for the UpgradeTask_Build number in the entities.xml
* If it is in "Pending" status, remove the entry and any other "Pending" tasks.
* Recover JIRA and import again

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When restoring a Cloud backup on another Jira Cloud site, the import fails with the following message:

"Error importing data: cloud.atlassian.logmon.laas.api.PrivacySafeException: Privacy-safe boxing of a com.atlassian.crowd.exception.runtime.OperationFailedException"

On the backend, however, we can see an exception "GroupAlreadyExists", status 409 meaning there is a conflict of information.

h3. Environment
* Cloud -> Cloud restoration

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Take a backup of a Jira Cloud
# Restore it on another Cloud

h3. Expected Results
Restoration completes successfully.

h3. Actual Results

It shows error:
{code}
"Error importing data: cloud.atlassian.logmon.laas.api.PrivacySafeException: Privacy-safe boxing of a com.atlassian.crowd.exception.runtime.OperationFailedException"
{code}

{code}

h3. Notes

* The bug most likely to happen on Cloud -> Cloud restoration
* The error message can have other causes.

h3. Workaround
# Remove users and groups from the entities.xml and import with one of the following options: 
(!) Please make a backup/copy of the Import File before performing any changes to it
Once that is done, please run one of the following blocks at the OS Level (preferably through a Linux Terminal) the below SED commands against the XML file:
{code}
sed -i '/<User id="/d' entities.xml
sed -i '/<Group id="/d' entities.xml
sed -i '/<Membership id="/d' entities.xml
sed -i '/<GroupAttribute id="/d' entities.xml
{code}
(i) In case you are using MacOS, the below SED syntax is more suitable for the MacOS Terminal:
{code}
sed -i '' '/<User id="/d' entities.xml
sed -i '' '/<Group id="/d' entities.xml
sed -i '' '/<Membership id="/d' entities.xml
sed -i '' '/<GroupAttribute id="/d' entities.xml
{code}
# Contact Atlassian Support to manually delete the add-on users

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When importing a CSV file and the *Issue key* is defined as a column, in the *Issue key* does not exist, JIRA will "assume" the Issue and update accordingly based on the Issue number.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Have an existing Issue in JIRA (ie: SCRUM-379)
# Prepare a CSV file to update any given field (ie: Summary) using an Issue key that does not exist
{noformat}
IssueKey, Summary
RUBBISH-379, Summary update 1
{noformat}
# Import the CSV file and make sure the *Issue key* is mapped
 !External_System_Import_-_JIRA.png|thumbnail! 

Please note, this bug can also impact if the issue key is moved under a different project previously. ie. ABC-100 is moved as XYZ-200. The CSV import having issue number for UVW-100 will eventually update XYZ-200 to ABC-200.

h3. Expected Results

Issue key does not exist, I would expect the import to fail or do nothing.

h3. Actual Results

JIRA ignores the Project key (*SCRUM*) and looks for whatever Issue number it can match with (*379*) and updates that Issue.

 !_SCRUM-379__Summary_update_4_-_JIRA.png|thumbnail!  

h3. Notes

In the example I provided, I imported a CSV file to update the *Summary* field of Issue *RUBBISH-379*. This Issue does not exist and there is no *RUBBISH* Project on this instance.

The importer simply looked at the Project it was importing to (SCRUM) and found whatever Issue matched number 379.

h3.Workaround

There is no workaround. To avoid this, Issue creation and Issue update through a CSV file should be done separately to avoid this unwanted updates.
fields.summary: Valid Issue key not required to update an Issue through CSV import

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Customers who are migrating into the Cloud Environment have noticed that the Mail Handlers that were created in their Old Instance were not present after migration
The Mail Servers are Imported in

h3. Environment
* Jira Server 7.5.0 > Cloud 
* Cloud > Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create backup of Jira 
# Import it into another Cloud Instance

h3. Expected Results
All Mail Servers and their Associated Mail Handlers are Imported in

h3. Actual Results
Mail Servers are Imported in, however the corresponding Mail Handlers are not
The Default Cloud Mail Handler is created 

Example Server Mail Handlers:
!ServerMail.png|thumbnail!  
Example of Cloud Post Import:
!CloudMail-PostImport.png|thumbnail! 
 
h3. Notes
Engaged with Server Team and they mentioned that Mail Handlers are brought over during Server > Server migrations

h3.Workaround
Manually recreate Mail Handlers
fields.summary: Jira Mail Handlers not Added During Migration
Import fails with groups containing leading or trailing whitespace

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When you import a parent issue like a story with its subtasks using the external system import CSV the subtasks are not showing inside the parent issue, however, when you do an advance search the subtasks show a parent relation.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Export or create a CSV file with a parent issue and its subtasks
 # Use the external system import to import the CSV file into a Next-gen project
https://share.getcloudapp.com/NQu1e0wm

h3. Expected Results
The subtasks should be displayed inside the parent ticket or in the board when grouped by subtask

h3. Actual Results
No subtasks are displayed in the parent ticket just in the advanced search


h3. Workaround
Recreate the subtasks or first import all the issues into a Classic project and then move them to a Next-gen
Note: Trying to move them to reassign the parent is not working.
fields.summary: Parent - Subtask relationship is not showing on Next-gen projects when issues are imported from CSV

fields.description:
h3. Summary
JIRA Cloud Import fails when there is a user in the backup file that has the same email address but doesn't match case (has a mismatch uppercase or lowercase letter) to the 'site-admin' performing the import and the username is different.

The following error is shown on screen
{quote}
Unexpected error while restoring data: com.atlassian.crowd.exception.runtime.OperationFailedException: Failed to import user remotely
{quote}

JIRA locks and requires a restart.

h3. Example:
Existing site-admin doing the import:
* username: admin
* email address: test@test.com

User in the backup file:
* username: Fred
* email address: Test@test.com

That is the only scenario when it fails. Identical username or email address will be skipped during the user during import.

h3. Environment
* JIRA Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Customers find this problem when migrating from Server to Cloud and using the same email address that was on their server site.

To force the error do:
# Generate a backup file from Cloud
# Extract entities.xml from zip
# Manually edit the entities.xml file and set the admin user's email address to any other user on the xml but changing a letter to uppercase.
# Zip the backup
# Login to Cloud using the same admin email address used on step 3
# Import in Cloud 

h3. Expected Results
JIRA import succeeds

h3. Actual Results
Error is shown on screen and JIRA is locked.

JIRA logs:
{noformat}
Caused by: com.atlassian.idp.client.exceptions.BadRequestException: {"errorType":"UserAlreadyExists","message":"Duplicate email address: Test@test.com","data":"Test@test.com"}
{noformat}

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Import status changed history through JSON does not display as status changed in issue history. It displays the action but it displays as a plain text. The HistoryItems were transformed into a generic map
the statements are different when performing it through the UI and when importing using the JSON file
through the UI, it shows user changed the status while the JSON shows updated

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a JSON file to import issue history of status being changed

h3. Expected Results
At the issue history, it is expected that the status is displayed with colored status
 !image-2020-08-13-11-01-27-165.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Actual Results
The HistoryItems were transformed into a generic map
 !image-2020-08-13-11-01-09-613.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Import status changed history through JSON does not display as status changed in issue history

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Importing Due Date in the format set in the Global Settings (look and feel) causes the import to fail for Due Date field as it uses its own format YYYY/MMM/dd.
When importing the Due Date value, it gives a warning that Jira was unable to parse the value.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Have the look and feel set to display and use dates in the format MMM/dd/yy
# Have a CSV file to import and set the Due Date
# At the CSV import wizard set the date format to match your data format MMM/dd/yy 

h3. Expected Results
The import should finish with success mapping the Due Date field as expected.

h3. Actual Results
It gives an error that Jira was unable to parse the date format.

h3. Workaround
Use the default format at the CSV file (I.e 03/Mar/20 12:00 AM) and at the import wizard leave the default format suggestion: dd/MMM/yy h:mm a
fields.summary: Unable to set Due Date field using the Look and Feel configuration

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Importing data to Cloud does not include group description

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Generate backup from the source instance
# Perform an import on the target instance

h3. Expected Results
* Group description imported 

h3. Actual Results
* Group description not imported
fields.summary: Importing data to Cloud does not include group description

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
In *Import issues from CSV*, the *Attachments* field is not available in the import wizard 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # In Jira > Search > Advanced issue search > *...* > Import issues from CSV
 # Choose a CSV file > Navigate to field mapping page > Try to map *Attachments* field

h3. Expected Results
Users/non-admins should be able to map the *Attachments* field in the import wizard

h3. Actual Results
The *Attachments* field is not available 

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Attachments field is not available in Import issue from CSV

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When importing comments to issues in Next-Gen projects an error is thrown using the External System Import.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a CSV file containing Summary,Issue key,Issue id,Comment,Issue Type, Parent
 # Try to import the CSV file.

h3. Expected Results

The fields are going to be updated and the comment will be imported.
h3. Actual Results

The following error is thrown:
{panel}
{color:#ff0000}Unexpected failure occurred. Importer will stop immediately. Data may be in an unstable state: At least one given IssueParentAssociations must not be empty!{color}
{panel}
h3. Workaround

What happens is that the importer will look for a Parent Association for the imported issue and if it does not exists it fails. To work around the behavior create a new Epic and add all the issues into it and then perform the import mapping the Parent -> Parent ID with an empty value.
fields.summary: When importing comments to issues in Next-Gen projects an error is thrown

fields.description:

# Create a CSV file including the summary, the description, and the type of the issue; don't include the "Component" field

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When a Jira site is migrated to another hosting location, the _default user time zone_ parameter gets reset to UTC
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Change the _default user time zone_ parameter to something else than UTC
 # Migrate the site to a different hosting location

h3. Expected Results
The _default user time zone_ parameter remains the same

h3. Actual Results
The _default user parameter_ gets reset to UTC

h3. Workaround
Change the parameter back to the desired value after the migration
fields.summary: Migrating the Jira site to another hosting location resets the "default user time zone" parameter to UTC

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Currently, if a user uses a CSV file which contains locked field and also some values which could be new custom field option, the import process will be adding new custom filed options.

This could be problematic for the Jira Software custom fields like "Epic Status".
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Import a CSV file that contains Epic issues with new values for the "Epic Status" custom field

h3. Expected Results

No new options should be added to the locked custom field
h3. Actual Results

The options are added and cannot be removed on the UI
h3. Workaround

The [Jira Cloud REST API|https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/jira/platform/rest/v3/intro/] can be used to remove the options from LOCKED custom fields.
# Get the <customFieldID> from the URL opened from the "..." menu and "View field information"
# Get the <customFieldContextID> by opening the URL below, replacing the <customFieldID>:
#* https://<siteName>.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/field/customfield_<customFieldContextID>/contexts
# Replace the <customFieldID> and <customFieldContextID> from the URL below and open it on the browser to get the <optionID> of the undesired custom field option
#* https://<siteName>.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/field/customfield_<customFieldID>/context/<customFieldContextID>/option
# Generate an [Atlassian account API token|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/api-tokens-938839638.html] that will be used as authentication method
# Execute this API call to delete the option using your email and API token, replace the <customFieldID>, <customFieldContextID> and <optionID>:
{code}
curl --request DELETE \
  --url 'https://<siteName>.atlassian.net/rest/api/3/field/customfield_<customFieldID>/context/<customFieldContextID>/option/<optionID>' \
  --user '<email>:<apiToken>'
{code}

If the response is empty and 200, it's done.
fields.summary: Jira External System Import (JIM) can create new options for LOCKED custom fields

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When a card is a copy of another card on the same Trello Board, the comments are missing after importing into Jira.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

1. On a Trello Board, Create a new card ( say abc) > Add a comment to it > Copy the card (see abc copied)

2. The copied card is getting imported into Jira without having comments on it.
h3. Expected Results

The Trello copied cards should get imported to Jira along with the comments.
h3. Actual Results

The Trello copied cards are getting imported to Jira missing all the comments of copied card.
h3. Workaround

Don't import the copied Trello cards.
fields.summary: On Trello import the Jira, the copied cards should get imported along with comments

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Using the CSV importer to import users into issues on Jira is very useful when handling bulk operations. Based on this [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/importing-data-from-csv-776636762.html], users field accepts email / accountId. however the Watcher field doesn't accept email

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a CSV importer file to add watchers into an issue
 ||Issue Key || Watchers || Watchers || Watchers||
|ABC-123| email1 | email2| email3|

h3. Expected Results
users should be added to the issues as Watchers

h3. Actual Results
An error is triggered that *Watcher* 'johndoe@example.com' *doesn't have an account in JIRA*


h3. Workaround

Basically, the alternative is to use accountId instead. However, it is important that if email address is available, it would be easier to identify who are the users when configuring the CSV file.
fields.summary: Watcher field is not consistent with the user picker field using CSV  Import
